author: adamdriscoll
body:
In PowerShell v6, Convert(To\From)-Json uses Newtonsoft.Json. ConvertTo-Json acknowledges JsonIgnoreAttributes but does not honor JsonPropertyAttributes.  have some objects that are decorated with these attributes and serialize differently between ASP.NET and PowerShell. I've had to make a hacked version of ConvertTo-Json to support these attributes. For me, it results in a difference in casing which causes my JavaScript code to fail. 

I propose that the JSON cmdlets honor the JsonPropertyAttributes placed on properties.

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
It looks like instead of letting Newtonsoft  handle the serialization, we hit this code path

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/0f036d9939d2d6ba4430baf73dc3c11ebd46e241/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility/commands/utility/WebCmdlet/ConvertToJsonCommand.cs#L398

Which essentially converts the object to a dictionary and striping it of the any useful JSON attributes.

At this point, I'm already convinced the right direction for JSON is to just wrap Newtonsoft and stop using our own logic as well as make some of the newtonsoft features available. This probably needs to be new cmdlets. Because pretty much everything we do at this point is a breaking change in the current cmdlets. 

As for fixing this in the current cmdlets... I have some (bad) ideas such as re-inventing the wheel to inspect the attributes on the object properties.. Maybe before we make the object ditcionary, we test the object for Json related attributes and pass the object directly to NewtonSoft... but that has depth issues.

comments.author: iSazonov
adamdriscoll
markekraus
comments.body:
For clarity, the depth issues I was referring to are in regards to to the possible solution of inspecting the object for json attributes.. the question od how deep to inspect and how to detect looping etc..

I'm not fond of having new cmdlets, but the way I see it working is that we'd add the new cmdlets, mark the old ones as deprecated (with warnings), then remove them 3 minor version later and adding the original cmdlets names as aliases to the new ones. In theory, the new cmdlets would "just work" in most cases, but obviously, there would be subtle differences.

comments.author: felixfbecker
comments.body: Using NewtonSoft directly would be awesome because almost all API C# clients use it to decorate their attributes - in C#/PowerShell they will be PascalCased, but for JSON they usually need to be lowercased. So to support proper interop with APIs honoring `JsonPropertyAttribute` is crucial.
